context: (Scottish_Parliament) Stage 1 is the first, or introductory stage of the bill, where the minister or member in charge of the bill will formally introduce it to Parliament together with its accompanying documents u2013 Explanatory Notes, a Policy Memorandum setting out the policy underlying the bill, and a Financial Memorandum setting out the costs and savings associated with it. Statements from the Presiding Officer and the member in charge of the bill are also lodged indicating whether the bill is within the legislative competence of the Parliament. Stage 1 usually takes place, initially, in the relevant committee or committees and is then submitted to the whole Parliament for a full debate in the chamber on the general principles of the bill. If the whole Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principles of the bill, it then proceeds to Stage 2.
modContext: Stage 1 within the Scottish Parliament refers to the initial phase of a bill. During this stage, the responsible minister or member will formally present the bill to Parliament. Alongside the bill, they will also provide supplementary documents such as Explanatory Notes, a Policy Memorandum explaining the underlying policy of the bill, and a Financial Memorandum outlining the associated costs and potential savings.The Presiding Officer and the member responsible for the bill provide statements to demonstrate whether the bill falls within the Parliament's legislative competence.Typically, Stage 1 commences in the respective committee or committees and subsequently progresses to the entire Parliament for a comprehensive discussion in the chamber regarding the fundamental principles of the bill.If there is unanimous agreement in Parliament during a vote on the fundamental principles of the bill, it will move forward to Stage 2.
question: what stage usually takes place in the irrelevant committees?
answer: the context does not provide information on what stage usually takes place in the irrelevant committees
modAnswer: stage 1 usually takes place in the respective committees

context: (Huguenot) In the early years, many Huguenots also settled in the area of present-day Charleston, South Carolina. In 1685, Rev. Elie Prioleau from the town of Pons in France, was among the first to settle there. He became pastor of the first Huguenot church in North America in that city. After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian nobility and descent, including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, Jean Postell of Dieppe France, Alexander Pepin, Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France, and Jacques de Bordeaux of Grenoble, immigrated to the Charleston Orange district. They were very successful at marriage and property speculation. After petitioning the British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies, they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger. Some of their descendants moved into the Deep South and Texas, where they developed new plantations.
modContext: During the initial years, a significant number of Huguenots also made their home in the region that is now known as Charleston, South Carolina.In the year 1685, ReverendElie Prioleau, who hailed from the French town of Pons, was one of the initial settlers in the area.He assumed the role of pastor at the earliest Huguenot church established in North America situated within that city.Following the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, a number of Huguenot families of noble lineage and ancestry, such as the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, as represented by Edmund Bohun from Suffolk, England; Jean Postell from Dieppe, France; Alexander Pepin; Antoine Poitevin from Orsement, France; and Jacques de Bordeaux from Grenoble, decided to migrate to the Charleston Orange district.They achieved great success in both their marriage and property investments.Following their request to the British Crown to acquire land in the Baronies in 1697, they experienced success as slaveholders on the plantations located along the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley, and Santee Rivers. These plantations were acquired from Edmund Bellinger, a British Landgrave.Their offspring later migrated to the Deep South and Texas, and there they established and managed new plantations.
question: what french city was alexander pepin originally from?
groundTruth: newton was limited by denver's defense
answer: alexander pepin was originally from dieppe, france

context: (Fresno,_California) Passenger rail service is provided by Amtrak San Joaquins. The main passenger rail station is the recently renovated historic Santa Fe Railroad Depot in Downtown Fresno. The Bakersfield-Stockton mainlines of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway and Union Pacific Railroad railroads cross in Fresno, and both railroads maintain railyards within the city; the San Joaquin Valley Railroad also operates former Southern Pacific branchlines heading west and south out of the city. The city of Fresno is planned to serve the future California High Speed Rail.
modContext: Amtrak San Joaquins provides passenger rail service in Fresno, California.Downtown Fresno is home to the recently restored and historic Santa Fe Railroad Depot, which serves as the primary passenger rail station.In Fresno, the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway and Union Pacific Railroad have mainlines that intersect. Both railways have railyards within the city. Additionally, the San Joaquin Valley Railroad operates former branchlines of the Southern Pacific Railway that extend west and south from Fresno.The city of Fresno is currently being developed to accommodate the impending construction of the California High-Speed Rail project.
question: what mainlines head west and south from the city?
answer: the san joaquin valley railroad operates former southern pacific branchlines heading west and south out of the city
modAnswer: the context does not provide information on what mainlines head west and south from the city

context: (Jacksonville,_Florida) According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 874.3 square miles (2,264 km2), making Jacksonville the largest city in land area in the contiguous United States; of this, 86.66% (757.7 sq mi or 1,962 km2) is land and ; 13.34% (116.7 sq mi or 302 km2) is water. Jacksonville surrounds the town of Baldwin. Nassau County lies to the north, Baker County lies to the west, and Clay and St. Johns County lie to the south; the Atlantic Ocean lies to the east, along with the Jacksonville Beaches. The St. Johns River divides the city. The Trout River, a major tributary of the St. Johns River, is located entirely within Jacksonville.

Patrick's Day parade in Dublin is a beloved annual tradition. Every year, thousands of people gather to celebrate Ireland's patron saint and the country's rich cultural heritage. The parade is a vibrant display of artistic performances, colorful floats, and marching bands. It is a festive and lively event that showcases the Irish spirit and brings people from all walks of life together in a joyful celebration. Participants dress in green and wave Irish flags as they march down the streets of Dublin, creating a sea of color and enthusiasm. The parade is followed by numerous events and activities, including live music performances, traditional dancing, and a fireworks display. It is a day of joy, laughter, and camaraderie that truly embodies the spirit of St. Patrick's Day.The city is divided by the Johns River.The St. John River is significantly fed by the Trout River, a substantial tributary.The Johns River is situated fully within the boundaries of Jacksonville.

context: (Immune_system) Immunology is a science that examines the structure and function of the immune system. It originates from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease. The earliest known reference to immunity was during the plague of Athens in 430 BC. Thucydides noted that people who had recovered from a previous bout of the disease could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second time. In the 18th century, Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion venom and observed that certain dogs and mice were immune to this venom. This and other observations of acquired immunity were later exploited by Louis Pasteur in his development of vaccination and his proposed germ theory of disease. Pasteur's theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of disease, such as the miasma theory. It was not until Robert Koch's 1891 proofs, for which he was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1905, that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease. Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901, with the discovery of the yellow fever virus by Walter Reed.
modContext: Immunology is a scientific field that investigates the organization and operation of the immune system.The origins of this concept can be traced back to the field of medicine and early research on understanding the factors that contribute to the body's ability to resist and defend against diseases.The plague of Athens in 430 BC is the earliest recorded mention of immunity.Thucydides observed that individuals who had previously been infected with the disease were able to care for the sick without becoming reinfected.During the 18th century, Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis conducted experiments involving scorpion venom. He noticed that some dogs and mice displayed immunity to the venom.Louis Pasteur utilized these and other observations of acquired immunity in the advancement of vaccination and his proposition of the germ theory of disease.Pasteur's theory contradicted contemporary theories of disease, including the miasma theory.Microorganisms were not confirmed as the cause of infectious disease until Robert Koch provided proof in 1891. For his findings, Koch received a Nobel Prize in 1905.In 1901, Dr. Walter Reed made a significant breakthrough in confirming viruses as human pathogens when he discovered the yellow fever virus.
question: whose theories supported the miasma theory?
answer: the text does not provide information on whose theories supported the miasma theory
modAnswer: louis pasteur's germ theory of disease contradicted the miasma theory

context: (Scottish_Parliament) Bills can be introduced to Parliament in a number of ways; the Scottish Government can introduce new laws or amendments to existing laws as a bill; a committee of the Parliament can present a bill in one of the areas under its remit; a member of the Scottish Parliament can introduce a bill as a private member; or a private bill can be submitted to Parliament by an outside proposer. Most draft laws are government bills introduced by ministers in the governing party. Bills pass through Parliament in a number of stages:
modContext: There are various ways in which bills can be introduced to the Scottish Parliament. One method is for the Scottish Government to propose new laws or changes to existing laws as a bill. Additionally, a committee of the Parliament can present a bill within its specific area of responsibility. Members of the Scottish Parliament also have the ability to introduce bills as private members. Furthermore, outside individuals or organizations can submit private bills to the Parliament for consideration.The majority of draft laws are proposed by ministers from the ruling party.
question: how do bills pass through parliament?
answer: bills pass through parliament in a number of stages
